Fall Arts Preview | Louisville theater season is loaded

Previewing a theater season in Louisville is like going to a casino buffet — so much to choose from, and variety as well.

Fall Arts Preview | Louisville theater season is loaded

Elizabeth Kramer, ekramer@courier-journal.com 8:47 a.m. EDT August 17, 2014

The Tony Award-winning revival of the musical “Pippin” directed by Diane Paulus comes to Louisville this season. (Photo: Photo by Joan Marcus )

20 CONNECTTWEET 1 LINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Previewing a theater season in Louisville is like going to a casino buffet — so much to choose from, and variety as well.

From the veteran theater companies to the smaller outfits and community theaters, Louisville audiences can find the classics, recent Broadway musical hits, stories that hit close to home, works by new playwrights (that's not just something at Actors during the Humana Festival of New American Plays) and even, at least this season, absurdist theater.

Picking just five is arduous and conjures questions. What about CenterStage and its production of Sondheim's "Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street" during its 100th-anniversary season? What about Theatre502's "Red Speedo" by Lucas Hnath, the playwright who has had three works in the Humana Festival?

Also to consider are Oscar Wilde's "The Importance of Being Earnest" by The As Yet Unnamed Theatre Company and Louisville Repertory Company's "dirty sexy derby play" by Louisville playwright Brian Walker.

That's not even counting the various community theater companies that offer favorites that are fun to see for the first time or revisit. Just look through the listings. Oh, but I had to pick five. So, here they are.

2014-15 FALL ARTS CALENDAR

Pop music: Critic's picks

Classical music: Critic's picks
Classical music calendar

Theater: Critic's picks
Theater calendar

Dance: Critic's picks
Dance calendar

Visual arts: Critic's picks
Visual arts calendar

"Love's Labour's Lost," Actors Theatre of Louisville, Sept. 2-21: While Actors has many productions worth choosing this season — "Tribes" by Nina Raine, Tarell Alvin McCraney's "The Brothers Size" and a remounting of Naomi Iizuka's "At the Vanishing Point" with original music by Ben Sollee — a likely choice for the most adventurous goes to this Shakespeare comedy in the hands of Steve Epp, Nathan Keepers and Dominique Serrand.

All three were involved with the now defunct but highly creative Minneapolis company Theatre de la Jeune Lune, which Serrand co-founded. Since that company folded, the three have been involved in another venture called The Moving Company.

Their upcoming reimagined adaptation of the Bard's comedy promises to be in line with previous inventive works they were part of at Actors. Those include include the 2004 production of Moliere's "The Miser" (Serrand directed both Epp and Keepers, who were in the cast) and the 2010 Humana Festival's selection "Fissures" (with Serrand and Epp as co-writers and Keepers in the cast).

One mark of their work is its intense physicality. Just last season, audiences got to see a dose of that when Keepers played Andy Grotelueschen in the theater's production of "Noises Off."

"The Bald Soprano," Savage Rose Classical Theatre Company at The Bard's Town Theatre, Sept. 5-7: Anyone aware of the Theatre of the Absurd, where situations in which meaning is elusive give way to moments that can be both comedic and tragic, likely knows of Eugene Ionesco's "The Bald Soprano." While the play is well-known, it isn't produced often. But last August, Savage Rose took on what can be a risky play to produce by staging a version adapted and directed by Tad Chitwood in a limited run.

Audience feedback signaled that the risk was worth taking and a remount was in order. So, audiences get another chance to see Chitwood's adaptation, which he also directs and which takes the characters out of post-World War II and England's dull middle class to place them in current America and its own customs.

"And in This Corner ... Cassius Clay," StageOne Family Theater, Kentucky Center, Jan. 24-Feb. 14: Anyone over age 45 likely remembers the 1975 hit "Black Superman (Muhammad Ali)." The song came at a time when Ali was everywhere following his legendary fight with George Foreman in Kinshasa, dubbed The Rumble in the Jungle. But now, StageOne has commissioned Idris Goodwin, a playwright and spoken-word performer, to write "And in This Corner ... Cassius Clay" as part of the company's Mimi and Marshall Heuser New Play Development Series.

The play covers Ali's life when he was Cassius Clay Jr., growing up in segregated Louisville of the 1950s.

Goodwin has some hefty theatrical credentials, including writing residencies with Berkeley Repertory Theatre and the New Harmony Project. He's now developing new work with Denver Center Theatre Company. His play "How We Got On" premiered in Actors Theatre's 2012 Humana Festival before going on to other theaters across the country.

"Edith Can Shoot Things and Hit Them," Pandora Productions, Henry Clay Theatre, March 5-15: Pandora Productions has made a name for itself for its bold productions in both drama and comedy. (One of its special holiday productions years ago made me laugh harder than any production I can recall.)

For a company committed to works that "speak to the gay, lesbian, bi-sexual, transgender and questioning community," it has found works that run the gamut of human experience. One in this season's lineup — A. Rey Pamatmat's "Edith Can Shoot Things and Hit Them" — delighted audiences and reviewers when it premiered in Actors' 2010 Humana Festival and went on to productions at theaters across the country.

This gives Louisville audiences another chance to see it if they haven't already and others a chance to revisit this sweet story of a brother, Kenny, and sister, Edith, abandoned by their workaholic father. On a remote farm, they mostly fend for themselves, and Kenny finds his first love.

"Pippin," PNC Bank Broadway Across America Louisville, Kentucky Center, June 2-7: The Broadway Series has a lot to offer this season with the musicals "Newsies," "Once" and the return of "The Lion King." But "Pippin" looks to be the crowning glory.

The 2013 Broadway revival directed by Diane Paulus originated at American Repertory Theater and won Tony Awards for Best Revival of a Musical and Best Direction of a Musical. The touring production includes a few original cast members, including John Rubinstein, who originated the title role, now playing Pippen's father, Charlemagne or King Charles. Sasha Allen, a finalist on the fourth season of NBC's singing competition "The Voice," has been cast in the role of the Lead Player, putting her in the footsteps of Ben Vereen, who won a Tony in 1973 for originating the role, and Patina Miller, who won a Tony for her performance in the revival.

The touring "Pippen," like the Broadway production, also includes the acrobatics of the Montreal circus troupe Les 7 Doigts de la Main.

Reporter Elizabeth Kramer can be reached at (502) 582-4682. Follow her on Twitter at @arts_bureau.
